section.heading: Regulating the rental, leasing or bailment for consideration of any vessel, personal watercraft, parasail, or kite; exceptions; enforcement; penalties.

para.text: It is unlawful for any person to rent, lease, bail for consideration or otherwise provide transportation for remuneration of any kind either voluntary or involuntary, of any vessel, including but not limited to commercial vessels, personal watercraft, parasail, or kite on any waters within the city unless that person has first obtained a current business operating permit issued by the city. Each day of operation without such permit shall constitute a separate offense. Each location requires a separate business operating permit.
No such permit shall be issued by the city if the following requirements are not met:
The business tax division has verified and approved that:
The applicant has a zoning compliance certification duly issued pursuant to the zoning code; and
The applicant has paid the proper occupational license tax; and
The applicant has paid the proper business operating permit application fee; and

The applicant has and maintains commercial general liability insurance covering liability from applicant's watercraft business with a bodily injury and property damage limit of no less than one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) per occurrence and annual aggregate. A copy of the current insurance policy shall be kept, at all times, at the applicant's rental operations office.
The zoning administrator has verified and approved that:
Applicant's rental operations office is located at a land-based site; and

Applicant's land-based site has direct access to the beach. As used herein, "direct access" means the state of having access to the beach directly without traversing any public right-of-way, any beach, park, or land owned, leased, or operated by the city, any wetlands, mangroves on lands that have been set aside as mitigation, public lands set aside for conservation or preservation, mangroves growing along the shoreline on property owned by a governmental entity, or sovereign submerged land, or any residentially-zoned land.
The police department has verified and approved that:
Applicant has and maintains a working business telephone line and an operable marine VHF radio at its land-based rental operations office; and

Applicant has and maintains a manned, motorized chase vessel with operational marine radio in good running condition that meets all United States Coast Guard safety requirements, or in lieu of a chase vessel, applicant maintains a membership, contract or some other type of agreement with a commercial sea towing company; and

Applicant has and shall provide a list describing each vessel, personal watercraft, parasail, or kite it shall place in service for public use. Each unit shall be registered and numbered pursuant to F.S. §§ 327.10 and 327.11 as now enacted or hereafter amended and other applicable statutes and a Florida vessel registration number prominently affixed thereon; and
Applicant has and shall distribute a handout on boating safety rules to each person renting a vessel or personal watercraft; and

Applicant's vessel, personal watercraft, parasail or kite would not be a sight obstruction or any other obstruction which would prevent, hinder or impede the safe navigation or movement of other vessels on the water.

The administrative provisions, sanctions and appeals procedures prescribed in chapter 6 of this Code, not inconsistent with this section, are hereby adopted and expressly made applicable to this section.

It is unlawful for any person to conduct any business transaction, such as the exchange of consideration or remuneration for the rental, leasing, bailment or any other type of transaction of vessel, personal watercraft, parasail, or kite between the commercial rental operator thereof and the customer in a place other than the land-based site for which the business operating permit is issued.

It is unlawful for any person to lease, hire, or rent a vessel, personal watercraft, parasail, or kite to any person who is under sixteen (16) years of age or to lease, hire, or rent such vessel, personal watercraft, parasail, or kite to any other person, unless the commercial rental operator displays boating safety information about the safe and proper operation of such equipment and requires a signature by the customer that he or she has received instruction in the safe handling of the vessel, personal watercraft, parasail, or kite in compliance with standards established by the state as provided in F.S. § 327.54(4) or other applicable statutes as now enacted or hereafter amended.

It is unlawful for any person to sell, barter or exchange, or cause to be sold, bartered, or exchanged, tickets or any medium or device for the rental, leasing, or bailment for consideration or remuneration of any vessel, personal watercraft, parasail, or kite in violation of this section.

Any person offering, or causing to be offered, any vessel, personal watercraft, parasail, or kite for rent, lease, or bailment for consideration or remuneration shall, at all times, prominently display upon its rental operations office a written public notice of the terms of subsections (d), (e), (f), (h), (l), and (m).

Any vessel, personal watercraft, parasail, or kite used in violation of this section shall be subject to removal and impoundment by the city. The procedures for post impoundment hearings, release of impounded vehicles, and disposition of unrecovered vehicles prescribed in sections 15-128 through 15-130 of this Code are hereby adopted and expressly made applicable to vessels, personal watercraft, parasails, or kites. Thus, any reference to the terms "director," "parking division," "this chapter," "vehicle" or "motor vehicle," wherever they appear in said sections, shall be deemed to refer to "chief of police," "police department," "this section," and "vessels, personal watercraft, parasails, or kites" respectively.
This section is expressly made applicable to new and already existing vessel, personal watercraft, parasail, and kite rental operations.

This section does not apply to a performer engaged in a professional exhibition or a person preparing to participate or participating in a regatta, race, marine parade, tournament, or exhibition held in compliance with F.S. § 327.48 as now enacted or hereafter amended, or to law enforcement officers or city employees while performing their duties or operating in an emergency.
For purposes of this section, the following terms shall have the following meanings:
Mangroves on lands that have been set aside as mitigation shall have the same meaning as are and shall be defined by F.S. § 403.9325(4).
Personal watercraft shall have the same meaning as are and shall be defined by F.S. § 327.02(27).
Public lands set aside for conservation or preservation shall have the same meaning as are and shall be defined by F.S. § 403.9325(6).
Wetlands shall have the same meaning as are and shall be defined by F.S. § 373.019(22).
This section shall be enforced by the police department, any city code inspector or code enforcement officer, the county sheriff's office, and the Florida Fish and Wildlife Conservation Commission.

Except for subsection (e), any violation of this section shall be punished as provided in section 1-6 of this Code. Any person convicted of violating subsection (e) is guilty of a misdemeanor of the second degree, punishable as provided in F.S. § 775.082 or § 775.083 as now enacted or hereafter amended.

section.heading: Commercial vessel use of facilities owned, operated, managed and/or maintained by the city.

para.text: Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have meanings ascribed to them in this section except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:
Commercial vessel means:

Any vessel primarily engaged in the taking or landing of saltwater fish or saltwater products or freshwater fish or freshwater products, or any vessel licensed pursuant to F.S. § 379.361, from which commercial quantities of saltwater products are harvested, from within and without the waters of the State of Florida for sale either to the consumer, retail dealer, or wholesale dealer.
Any other vessel, except a recreational vessel as defined in F.S. § 327.07(34).
Director means the director of the parks and recreation department, or his or her designee.
Permittee means the owner of the commercial vessel, or his or her agent or representative.

Water taxi means every description of watercraft capable of being used as a means of transportation on water, and which is engaged in activity wherein a fee is paid by the user for transportation from one destination to another, and which is capable of operating without requiring the raising of any bridge.
The director is responsible for administering this section. The director has the authority to adopt rules for the implementation of this section.
The director may enter and inspect a commercial vessel for the purpose of ascertaining the state of compliance with this section and the rules promulgated by the director.
In addition to the requirements set forth in section 14-200 and chapter 16, all commercial vessels being utilized as commercial vessels in the city must obtain a permit.
The permit application must contain whatever information is required by the director, including but not limited to the following:
Proof of ownership or leasehold; and
Proof of compliance with all appropriate federal, state and local regulations; and
Vessel identification number; and

Proof of and the maintenance of the following minimum types of insurance during the term of the permit with companies authorized to do business in Florida, with an A.M. Best rating of B+ (or better), Class VI (or higher), or otherwise be acceptable to the city if not rated by A.M.:

General liability insurance: Commercial general liability insurance shall provide a minimum limit of coverage of no less than one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) for each occurrence and a general aggregate of two million dollars ($2,000,000.00) which shall also include the following coverages:
Premises/operations liability; and
Personal/advertising injury; and
Medical payments five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) minimum coverage limit; and
Fire damage one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) minimum coverage limit.
Participant liability coverage: Participant liability shall provide a minimum limit of coverage of no less than one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) for each occurrence and annual aggregate.

Liquor liability coverage: Liquor liability coverage shall be required if the applicant is involved in the sale and consumption of alcoholic beverages, as defined and regulated in chapter 3 of the City Code. Liquor liability coverage shall provide a coverage limit of no less than one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) for each occurrence.

Boat liability coverage: Boat liability coverage shall provide a minimum limit of coverage of no less than two million dollars ($2,000,000.00) for each occurrence and annual aggregate with no deductible.

Workers' compensation insurance and employer's liability insurance: Unless exempted by F.S. ch. 440, workers' compensation insurance or employer's liability insurance for all employees engaged in work under contract and/or for any contractor or subcontractor an applicant may hire and volunteers of applicant, any contractor or subcontractor, shall provide a minimum limit of coverage of no less than one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) bodily injury by accident and each accident; one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) bodily injury by disease policy limit; and one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) bodily injury by disease each employee. In lieu of workers' compensation insurance for volunteers, the city may accept either a waiver of liability in favor of the city or Medpay coverage for volunteers (subject to review and approval by the city's risk manager).

Longshoreman's and Harbor Worker's (USL & H) Insurance: Longshoreman's and harbor worker's insurance shall be in compliance with federal statutes for activities requiring work on or around a navigable waterway.

Certificates of insurance: Any insurance required for a permit pursuant to the requirements of this section, shall be subject to the review and approval of the city's risk management office and supported by evidence of approved insurance coverage for the term of the permit by a properly executed Accord twenty-five (25) certificates of insurance form. The certificate of insurance must be personally and manually signed by the authorized representative of the insurance company shown on the certificate. The city must be notified in writing at least thirty (30) days prior to any cancellation or modification of the insurance policy. All insurance policies required for a permit pursuant to this section shall name the city as an additional insured. The workers' compensation insurance and general liability insurance must also contain a waiver of subrogation in favor of the city. These polices must be primary and non-contributory. Subcontractor's commercial general liability must include applicant and the city as additional insureds. Applicant and the city shall be given all the same rights and insurance coverage under the general liability policy as given subcontractor. The city shall have the right to approve the form of the additional insured endorsement. Subcontractor's insurance shall be deemed primary.

A permit application fee shall be paid to the city at the time the permit application is submitted. A separate permit application fee is required for each vessel which is to be utilized as a commercial vessel.
If the permit application requirements are met, a permit may be issued.

Applicant shall renew every permit annually. A permit renewal fee shall be paid on or before the anniversary date of the original issuance. If a permit is not renewed within thirty (30) days of its due date, it shall be deemed abandoned and terminated.
No permit issued is transferable or assignable without prior approval by the director.

The fees collected under this section are fees paid for the purpose of the administration of this section and are declared to be regulatory fees in addition to and not in lieu of the occupation license tax imposed by chapter 24.
Fees—City council to establish. The city council shall have the authority to set permit fees by resolution.
Same—Types enumerated. Fees may be charged for the following:
Permit application; and
Permit renewal.
The director shall determine which city docking facilities are appropriate for loading and unloading of commercial vessels.
It is unlawful for permittees to use a loading/unloading zone in a manner which will deprive other commercial vessels of the use of such facilities.
All loading/unloading areas will be clearly marked by city signage. No permittee may post any signage or promotional information on city property.
It is unlawful for any vessel to dock at city facilities which have been designated as load/unload zones pursuant to this section without a permit as provided in this section.
Every commercial vessel shall post, in a conspicuous location on the vessel, the permit which has been issued pursuant to this section.
Every commercial vessel shall post, in a conspicuous location on the vessel, a sign which clearly explains and describes the fare, rate, or charge for the use of the vessel.
Prohibited activities. It is unlawful for a permittee to:
Solicit business by creating a loud or boisterous noise, including any voice amplification technique.
Convey a passenger to a place or location other than his requested destination.
Operate a commercial vessel while under the influence of alcohol or a controlled substance as defined by state statute.
Treat a passenger in an insolent or improper manner.

Refuse to transport a passenger to an advertised location unless the passenger is under the influence of alcohol or a controlled substance as defined by state statute, or otherwise not in control of his faculties to an extent that constitutes a hazard to the safety of the vessel or the occupants of the vessel.
The director may suspend a permit, if it is determined that:
The permittee has engaged in violations of this section; and
A statement contained in the application for permit is false; and
The permittee has exhibited a disregard for the public safety.
The director may revoke a permit if it determined that:
The permittee has repeatedly engaged in violations of this section.
The permittee has exhibited a disregard for the public safety.

The permittee may appeal a suspension or revocation by submitting a written appeal request to the neighborhood services administrator. The neighborhood services administrator shall issue a written decision within ten (10) days of receipt of the appeal.

section.heading: Prohibited anchoring or mooring of live-aboard vessels in jurisdictional waters.

para.text: Prohibited anchoring or mooring. It shall be unlawful to anchor or moor any live-aboard vessel within the city's jurisdictional waters unless the vessel is properly anchored or moored within a public or private marina or a designated mooring field.
Exceptions.This section shall not apply to any commercial fishing vessel. This section also shall not apply to any live-aboard vessel:
Responding to a good faith emergency, such as the failure of the vessel to operate, injury or illness suffered by the vessel's operator;
Moored to or docked at private property with the consent of the property owner, whether or not also anchored to secure the vessel; or
Anchored immediately adjacent to upland property owned or leased by the owner of the vessel, due to an inability to moor to or dock at the upland property.

Emergencies. In the event of a good faith emergency as provided for in subsection (a)(1)a above, the owner or occupant of the vessel shall immediately contact the Tampa Police Department at (813) 231-6130 and provide the following information with a request that it be relayed to the Marine Unit: i) the name of the caller; (ii) the name of the vessel's registered owner; iii) a description of the vessel; iv) the location of the vessel; v) the vessel's registration number; vi) the nature of the emergency; and vii) the amount of time required to remedy the situation. Compliance with this section is required within twenty-four (24) hours after the abatement of the emergency.

text.em: Enforcement, notice of violation, and penalties.

para.text: Enforcement. When applicable, violations of this section shall be enforced by the Tampa Police Department and any law enforcement agency having jurisdiction. Additional or supplemental means of enforcing this section may be used by the city, and nothing contained herein shall prohibit the city from seeking alternative enforcement mechanisms.

Person(s) responsible. Any person who owns, operates, or is otherwise in control of an unlawfully anchored or moored live-aboard vessel within the city's jurisdictional waters may be in violation of this section.

Notice of violation given. Prior to seeking any penalty as provided under sub-section (b)(4), an officer shall give a written notice of violation to any person(s) responsible under this section warning him or her that the live-aboard vessel is unlawfully anchored or moored and that it must be removed from the city's jurisdictional waters within ten (10) calendar days from the date of the notice or the person(s) is subject to penalties including arrest, fines, removal of the vessel, and costs for any removal. Written notice shall either be posted upon the vessel or hand-delivered to the person(s) responsible in substantially the following form:

section.text: NOTICE OF VIOLATION

This vessel, described as: ________________ is an unlawfully anchored or moored live-aboard vessel in the City of Tampa's jurisdictional waters located at (description/coordinates): _____________. Accordingly, you are being notified that you are in violation of section 14-212 of the City of Tampa's Code of Ordinances, and you must remove this live-aboard vessel from any unlawful anchoring or mooring in the City of Tampa's jurisdictional waters within ten (10) calendar days from the date of this notice. Failure to remove this live-aboard vessel from any unlawful anchoring or mooring in the City of Tampa's jurisdictional waters within ten (10) calendar days will subject you to punishment in accordance with section 1-6, City of Tampa Code of Ordinances, to include incarceration of up to sixty (60) days and/or fine of up to $500.00, or both incarceration and fine. In addition, the city may seek to remove the vessel and recover costs associated with any enforcement.
On the ___ day of _______________, 20____, this Notice was delivered as follows:
_____ Posted on vessel.
Name of Officer: ________________ TPD Report No.:________
Such notice shall be not less than eight (8) inches by ten (10) inches and, if posted, shall be sufficiently weatherproof to withstand normal exposure to the elements.

para.text: Penalties. Any person(s) responsible for an unlawfully anchored or moored live-aboard vessel which remains in violation after ten (10) calendar days from the date of the notice of violation was given shall be punished in accordance with the general penalties as provided under section 1-6 of this Code.

Penalties. If an unlawfully anchored or moored live-aboard vessel remains in violation after ten (10) calendar days from the date of the notice of violation is given to any person(s) responsible, then an officer may utilize the general penalties under section 1-6 of this Code against the person(s) responsible.

Repeat violation. The officer does not have to issue a notice of violation prior to seeking the penalties as provided under sub-section (b)(4) if the officer determines that the person is in repeat violation of section 14-212, pursuant to the definition provided in section 14-196.

annotation.doc: City of Tampa, Fla., Ord. No. 2018-72

section.heading: Removal of unlawfully anchored or moored live-aboard vessel in jurisdictional waters.

para.text: Qualification for removal and notice of removal. If the live-aboard vessel at issue under section 14-212 remains unlawfully anchored or moored in the city's jurisdictional waters after an officer has utilized the general penalties under section 1-6, then the live-aboard vessel shall also be subject to removal and disposal in accordance with this section and F.S. Chs. 327, 328, and 705, or amended or successor statutes. An officer will cause a written notice about the restriction on unlawful anchoring or mooring to be posted upon the live-aboard vessel in substantially the following form:

section.text: NOTICE OF REMOVAL

This vessel, described as: _________________________ is an unlawfully anchored or moored live-aboard vessel in the City of Tampa's jurisdictional waters located at (description/coordinates): _____________________________________________. The City of Tampa posted and/or hand-delivered a Notice of Violation on: ________________ informing you that this vessel was an unlawfully anchored or moored live-aboard vessel in the City of Tampa's jurisdictional waters. This vessel must be removed from any unlawful anchoring or mooring in the City of Tampa's jurisdictional waters within twenty-one (21) days. Otherwise, the vessel will be removed pursuant to sections 14-212 and 14-213 of the City of Tampa's Code of Ordinances and chapters 327, 328, and 705, Florida Statutes. The owner will be liable for the costs incurred for the removal, storage, and impoundment of the vessel. If the vessel is not recovered and outstanding costs are not paid within ninety (90) days after the unlawfully anchored or moored vessel is removed, then the city may dispose of the vessel in accordance with section 705.103, Florida Statutes, or any amended or successor statute.
This Notice was posted on this vessel on the ___ day of _____________, 20____.
Name of Officer: ____________ TPD Report No. _______

Such notice shall be not less than eight (8) inches by ten (10) inches and shall be sufficiently weatherproof to withstand normal exposure to the elements. In addition to posting, an officer shall make a reasonable effort to ascertain the name and address of the owner of the vessel. If the name and address of the owner of the vessel is reasonably available to the officer, he or she shall mail a copy of such notice to the owner within five (5) business days from the date of posting. The officer shall also contact the department of highway safety and motor vehicles in order to determine the name and address of the owner and any person who has filed a lien on the vessel as provided in F.S. § 328.15, or any amended or successor statute. On receipt of this information, the officer shall mail a copy of the notice by certified mail, return receipt requested, to the owner of the vessel and to the lienholder(s), if any, except that an officer who has issued an arrest or made a criminal notice to appear for a violation of F.S. § 823.11, to the owner of a derelict vessel is not required to mail a copy of the notice by certified mail, return receipt requested, to the owner.

para.text: Removal of vessel. If, twenty-one (21) days after posting the notice on the vessel, the owner or any person interested in the live-aboard vessel at issue in this section has not removed the vessel from any unlawful anchoring or mooring in the city's jurisdictional waters, the following shall apply:
The city may remove the vessel from the unlawful anchoring or mooring in accordance with this section and F.S. Chs. 327, 328, and 705, or any amended or successor statutes.
The owner of the vessel shall be responsible for all costs for the removal, storage, and impoundment of the vessel, which shall be paid prior to the release of the vessel to the owner or agent.
The owner shall be afforded the right to challenge the imposition of costs for removal, storage, and impoundment of the vessel pursuant to the hearing process outlined in section 14-214.

annotation.doc: City of Tampa, Fla., Ord. No. 2018-72

para.text: Request for hearing. Any vessel owner seeking to challenge the imposition of costs pursuant to this article for the removal, storage, and impoundment of the vessel by the city or any entity acting at the city's direction shall be entitled to a post-impoundment hearing before a hearing officer if:

The vessel's owner submits a request for a hearing within five (5) business days from the date the owner paid the city the costs for the removal, storage, and impoundment of the vessel on a hearing request form provided by the Marine Unit; or

If the vessel's owner does not have the financial means to pay the city for the costs for the removal, storage, and impoundment of the vessel, then the owner must submit both (a) a request for a hearing within five (5) business days from city's removal of the vessel from the unlawful anchoring or mooring on a hearing request form provided by the Marine Unit; and (b) an affidavit from the owner stating that the owner understands that the owner will be required to pay for all outstanding costs for the removal, storage, and impoundment of the vessel if the hearing officer determines that removal, storage, and impoundment of the vessel by the city or any entity acting at the city's direction pursuant to this article was in accordance with the applicable ordinances, statutes and regulations.

The request for hearing must include: a complete name and address of the owner requesting a hearing; the registered address of the vessel at issue; a copy of the vessel's registration; and a description of the dispute. The request for hearing may include the owner's phone number, the owner's e-mail address; and a statement as to whether the owner prefers that the notice of hearing be sent to the owner's physical address or to the owner's e-mail address.
Notice of hearing. If the vessel owner's request for hearing complies with the requirements addressed in the previous section, a Notice of Hearing shall be sent to the owner which states:
The date, time, and location of the hearing;
That an owner who elects to contest the imposition of costs and then fails to appear shall deemed to have waived a right to a hearing.

The notice of hearing shall be sent by mail to the owner's physical address or, if stated as a preference on the request for hearing, by e-mail to the e-mail address provided in the request to the owner requesting the hearing. A certification by the Marine Unit that the notice of hearing was mailed to the physical address or e-mailed to the e-mail address provided on the hearing request constitutes prima facie evidence that the owner requesting the hearing was served with the notice of hearing. Upon notification, the owner requesting the hearing is required to comply with the directions on the notice of hearing or waive the right to challenge the imposition of costs for the removal, storage, and impoundment of the vessel.

Continuance of Hearing. Any owner seeking to continue a hearing brought pursuant to this section shall deliver a written request for continuance to the Tampa Police Department, Attn.: Marine Unit, 411 N. Franklin St., Tampa, FL 33602 at least three (3) business days prior to the hearing date and shall be automatically granted one (1) continuance. The notice of the rescheduled hearing shall be sent to the owner in accordance with the procedures of subsection (b). An owner seeking any additional continuance(s) shall deliver a written request for continuance to Tampa Police Department, Attn.: Marine Unit, 411 N. Franklin St., Tampa, FL 33602 at least three (3) business days prior to the rescheduled hearing date; however, the city's decision to grant any further continuance(s) shall be at the city's discretion.

Conduct of hearing. Post-impoundment hearings shall be conducted on the same date and time as the city's parking violation hearings. The hearing officer shall have the power and authority to make any and all evidentiary findings of fact deemed necessary to make a determination as to whether the city or any entity acting at the city's direction properly impounded a vessel in accordance with this article and complied with the notice requirements of this article. If this hearing is brought pursuant to sections 14-212 and 14-213, then the hearing officer's determination may also analyze:
Whether the vessel at issue constitutes a "live-aboard vessel" as defined under this article;

Whether the vessel at issue was anchored or moored with the city's jurisdictional waters and if so, whether the vessel was properly anchored or moored within a city marina or designated mooring field;
Whether any exception exists under section 14-212(a)(1).

Determination of hearing officer. If the hearing officer determines by a preponderance of the evidence that the removal, storage, and impoundment of the vessel by the city or any entity acting at the city's direction pursuant to this article was in accordance with the applicable ordinances, statutes and regulations, then the city shall be entitled to keep all costs paid to the city for the removal, storage, and impoundment of the vessel. If the hearing officer determines by a preponderance of the evidence that the city's removal, storage, and impoundment of the vessel pursuant to this article was not in accordance with the applicable ordinances, statutes and regulations, then the owner shall be entitled to recover a refund of all costs paid to the city for the removal, storage, and impoundment of the vessel. These costs shall be refunded to the owner without interest and within thirty (30) days of the hearing officer's determination.

Exhaustion of administrative remedies. Anyone contesting the legality of any removal, storage, and impoundment of any vessel pursuant to this article shall be deemed to have exhausted the administrative remedies under this article once an adjudication or finding has been made by a hearing officer as provided in this section.

container.heading: ALARM SYSTEMS
container.annotation: 12 Cross reference— Fire prevention and protection, Ch. 11; police, Ch. 18.

section.heading: Definitions.
section.text: The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:

Alarm system means any mechanical, electrical or radio-controlled device which is designed to be used for the detection of any unauthorized entry into a building, structure or facility or for alerting others of the commission of an unlawful act within a building, structure or facility or both which emits a sound or transmits a signal or message when activated. Alarm systems include but are not limited to direct dial telephone devices, audible alarms and proprietor alarms. Excluded from the definition of alarm systems are devices which are designed or used to register alarms that are audible, visible or perceptible in or from any motor vehicle or auxiliary devices installed by telephone companies to protect telephone systems from damage or disruption of service.

Automatic dialing device means an alarm system which automatically sends over regular telephone lines, by direct connection or otherwise, a prerecorded voice message or coded signal indicating the existence of the emergency situation that the alarm system is designed to detect, but shall not include such telephone lines exclusively dedicated to an alarm system which are permanently active and terminate within the communication center of the police department or that of any other law enforcement agency.
Commercial premises means any structure or area that is not defined as a residential premises.

Such terminology does not include alarms caused by severe weather conditions or alarms caused by telephone line trouble, external power failures or other conditions which are clearly beyond the control of the alarm user.
Fee means an assessment of costs imposed pursuant to this chapter to defray the expense of responding to a false alarm.
Law enforcement officer means the chief of police of the city or his designee.
Residential premises means any structure or combination of structures which serve as a dwelling unit, including single-family and multifamily units.

section.heading: Response to false alarm; required reports; corrective action; fees and preventative maintenance.

para.text: [ Responsibility for false alarm. ] For the purpose of this division, responsibility for a false alarm shall be borne by the owner or lessee of the alarm system or his employee, servant or agent occupying and/or controlling the premises at the time of the occurrence of a false alarm.
[ Response; when. ] A response to a false alarm shall result when any police department personnel are dispatched to or otherwise learn of the activation of any alarm system.

False alarm fee. Subject to subsection (d), for each police response to a false alarm, the person who owns, operates, leases or controls the premises, commercial or residential, which is the source of the false alarm shall be charged a fee. Payment of this fee is due upon receipt of notice.

No fee shall be charged for the first three (3) false alarms from any single source. Provided, however, false alarms occurring prior to the effective date of this ordinance shall be included in determining the assessability of subsequent alarms. The fourth and all subsequent false alarms from any single source shall be subject to the fee assessment.

In the event an existing alarm system is replaced and proof of replacement is provided to the Tampa Police Department in the form of copies of applicable invoices, no fee shall be charged for the first three (3) false alarms occurring on or after the date of replacement. The fourth and all subsequent false alarms shall be subject to the fee assessment.

Intentional acts. No exemption from false alarm fees is provided at any time if the user, his agents, representatives, servants or employees, knowingly, and intentionally activate an alarm system for the purpose of unlawfully causing police response to a false alarm.

Successive alarms. False alarms that are subject to a fee assessment that occur successively during the same calendar day, and to which the police may make a separate response, shall incur a separate fee assessment for each response.

Audible alarms. In instances where alarms are audible outside the premises, it shall be considered an additional false alarm for each hour that such alarm remains audible after notification has been made to the alarm owner, or a designee that has been provided by the owner for the purpose of responding to alarms.
Preventative maintenance. It shall be the responsibility of the owner or lessee of an alarm system to cause the necessary maintenance required to prevent false alarm activation.

para.text: There is hereby created, pursuant to F.S. § 893.138 and the City of Tampa's Municipal Home Rule Powers, a Public Nuisance Abatement Board for the purpose of promoting, protecting, and improving the health, safety and welfare of the residents of the City of Tampa.
The Public Nuisance Abatement Board shall consist of seven (7) regular members who are residents of the City of Tampa and who will serve without pay.
The Public Nuisance Abatement Board may also have two (2) alternate members to serve in the absence of a regular member.

In order to streamline the number and functions of administrative boards in the City of Tampa government, the City of Tampa Code Enforcement Board is designated to act as the Public Nuisance Abatement Board.

In accordance with paragraph (c) above, the terms of the regular and alternate members of the Public Nuisance Abatement Board shall coincide with the terms of the regular and alternate members of the Code Enforcement Board.
The Public Nuisance Abatement Board shall elect its own chairman and vice-chairman and may conduct business with a quorum of four (4) members.

section.heading: Definitions.
section.text: As used in this article:
Board means the Public Nuisance Abatement Board of the City of Tampa.

Board Attorney means the City Attorney or his or her designee, who shall advise the Board regarding the organization of the board, the conduct of its hearings, and the exercise of its powers. The Board Attorney shall not prosecute cases before the Board and shall not exercise supervision over the Prosecuting Attorney when acting in that capacity.

Controlled substance means any substance named or described in F.S. § 893.03; any substance sold in lieu of a controlled substance in violation of F.S. § 817.563; any imitation controlled substance defined in F.S. § 817.564; or any "legend drug" or "prescription drug" as defined in F.S. § 499.003.

Operator means the person operating a place or premises subject to this article. The term includes, but is not limited to, owners, tenants, subtenants, and persons having operational control over the place or premises.

Owner means the owner of the real property upon which the place or premises is located. In cases where the owner and the operator are the same person, the terms "owner" and "operator" are used interchangeably in this article.

Place or premises means real property and its appurtenances and structures thereon as described in the deed or other instrument of conveyance as recorded in the Public Records of Hillsborough County, Florida. The term includes but is not limited to parking lots and other areas open to the general public or to invitees or licensees.

Prosecuting Attorney means a regular or special assistant City Attorney who shall prosecute cases before the Board. The Prosecuting Attorney shall exercise independent judgment, and shall not, with respect to such cases, be subject to supervision by the Board Attorney.
Public nuisance conduct means the conduct described in section 14-293(c)—(e).
Recurring public nuisance conduct means any single or multiple instance of the conduct described in section 14-293(c) occurring during the effective term of an order entered by the Board.
Respondent means the owner, operator, and any other person against whom a complaint is brought pursuant to this article.

section.heading: Powers of the board.
section.text: The Public Nuisance Abatement Board shall have the power to:

para.text: Adopt rules for the conduct of its hearings and establish procedures;
Take testimony and receive documentary evidence;
Hear complaints and declare as a public nuisance any place or premises, that has been used:
On more than two (2) occasions within a six-month period, as the site of a violation of F.S. § 796.07;
On more than two (2) occasions within a six-month period, as the site of the unlawful sale, delivery, manufacture, or cultivation of any controlled substance;

On one (1) occasion as the site of the unlawful possession of a controlled substance, where such possession constitutes a felony and that has been previously used on more than one (1) occasion as the site of the unlawful sale, delivery, manufacture, or cultivation of any controlled substance;
By a criminal street gang for the purpose of conduction a pattern of criminal street gang activity as defined by F.S. § 874.03;
On more than two (2) occasions within a six-month period, as the site of a violation of F.S. § 812.019, relating to dealing in stolen property; or

On at least three (3) occasions within a six-month period based on the offense date(s) of the citations, as the site of a violation of Tampa City Code or Ordinances chapter 14, article III, section 14-153 or section 14-154, relating to the nuisance associated with unreasonably excessive noise, where the citations have resulted in payment of the citation, a finding of violation by a court, or default;
On more than two (2) occasions as the site of a violation of F.S. Ch. 499, relating to misbranded drugs or cosmetics;
As a pain-management clinic, as described in F.S. § 458.3265 or § 459.0137, and has been used on more than two (2) occasions within a six-month period as the site of a violation of:
§ 784.011, § 784.021, § 784.03, or § 784.05, relating to assault and battery;
§ 810.02, relating to burglary;
§ 812.014, relating to theft;
§ 812.131, relating to robbery by sudden snatching; or
§ 893.13, relating to the unlawful distribution of controlled substances;
On more than one (1) occasion within an eighteen-month period as the site of the combination of any of the following crimes against persons;
§ 782.04, § 782.051, or § 782.065, relating to murder or attempted murder;
§ 782.07, relating to manslaughter;
§ 784.021, relating to aggravated assault;
§ 784.045, relating to aggravated battery;
§ 784.03, relating to felony battery;
Ch. 794, relating to sexual battery;
§ 812.13, relating to robbery;
§ 787.06, relating to human trafficking;
Ch. 790, relating to the unlawful use or possession of a weapon or firearm, discharging a firearm, or a felon in possession of a firearm;
Order the abatement of a declared public nuisance upon clear and convincing evidence that said place or premises has been used as set forth in paragraph (c) above;

A public nuisance may be established if the conduct described herein occurs in the adjacent parcel or public right-of-way, and there is a showing by clear and convincing evidence that the incident arose out of or originated from the place or premises; and
Issue orders having the force of law consistent with authority contained herein and in F.S. § 893.138.

para.text: The Prosecuting Attorney may file a complaint with the Secretary to the Board using information provided by the Police Department or any other appropriate city department.
The complaint will allege the facts necessary to demonstrate a place or premises is the site of public nuisance conduct.

The complaint shall name the owner and, if appropriate, the operator as respondents. If a place or premises is leased to or under the operational control of more than one (1) person, a failure to name all such persons as respondents shall not prejudice the right of the city to proceed against those persons who, in the judgment of the Prosecuting Attorney, are responsible for the occurrence of public nuisance conduct at the place or premises.
Any employee, officer or resident of the City of Tampa may file a verified complaint with the Secretary to the Board alleging that a place or premises is the site of public nuisance conduct.

The verified complaint shall be reviewed for legal sufficiency by the Board Attorney. In reviewing a complaint for legal sufficiency, the Board Attorney shall evaluate whether the material allegations of the complaint, if true, would support a finding by the Board that the property is a public nuisance.
If the Board Attorney finds that the verified complaint is legally sufficient, such finding shall be reduced to writing and provided to the Secretary.

Upon the receipt of a complaint from the Prosecuting Attorney or the receipt from the Board Attorney that a verified complaint is legally sufficient, the Secretary shall notify the Chairman of the Board who may call a hearing of the Board within thirty (30) days following receipt of the complaint.

The Secretary shall furnish a Notice of Hearing along with a copy of the complaint, to the respondent(s), or in the case where a respondent is a corporation, the registered agent, at the last known address, by one (1) of the following methods:
mail, certified return receipt requested, or
Personal service not less than three (3) days prior to a scheduled hearing before the Public Nuisance Abatement Board.
The Notice of Hearing shall contain:
The owner's name,
The address of the property where the alleged acts occurred, and
The date, time and place of the hearing.

para.text: The Board shall conduct a public hearing on the complaint, receiving any evidence, including evidence of the general reputation of the place or premises.
All testimony shall be under oath and recorded on audio tape or by other means.

If the case is brought by the Prosecuting Attorney, said attorney shall present evidence before the Board on behalf of the city. If the case is brought by an employee, officer or resident of the city, said employee, officer, or resident shall present the evidence before the Board.
The respondent(s) shall have an opportunity to present evidence in his defense.
All parties shall have an opportunity to present evidence and argument on all issues involved, conduct cross examination and submit rebuttal evidence.
The Board may consider any evidence, including, but not limited to, evidence of the general reputation of the place or premises.
Formal rules of evidence shall not apply, but fundamental due process shall govern the proceedings.

In any case brought by the Prosecuting Attorney on behalf of the city, the city shall have the burden of proving the existence of an unlawful public nuisance by competent and substantial evidence sufficient to meet the clear and convincing standard of proof,

In any case brought by an employee, officer or resident of the city, said employee, officer or resident shall have the burden of proving the existence of an unlawful public nuisance by competent and substantial evidence sufficient to meet the clear and convincing standard of proof.

If the respondent(s) have been properly noticed in regard to the hearing before the Board and if any respondent fails to appear, the Board may proceed with a hearing in absentia on the merits of the alleged violation. Any findings or order resulting from such hearing are valid and binding upon the respondents who have been properly noticed in regard to the hearing.
At the conclusion of the hearing and after considering all evidence presented at such hearing, the Board shall issue findings of fact based upon the evidence presented and made part of the record.
If the Board finds that the allegations of the complaint have not been proved, the Board shall dismiss the complaint.
If the Board finds that a sufficient number of the allegations of the complaint have been proved, the Board may declare the property to be an unlawful public nuisance.

If the Board declares that the property is an unlawful public nuisance, the Board may then consider the appropriate remedy, at the same meeting or at a later regular meeting or special meeting called for such purpose. The Board may, following its consideration of the appropriate remedy, enter an order requiring the owner of such place or premises to adopt such procedure as may be appropriate under the circumstances to abate any such nuisance. In addition to entering an order to stop the nuisance, the Board may enter an order immediately prohibiting:
The maintaining of the nuisance;
The operating or maintaining of the place or premises, including the closure of the place or premises or any part thereof; or
The conduct, operation, or maintenance of any business or activity on the premises which is conducive to such nuisance.
The findings and orders shall be by motion adopted by a majority of those present and voting. Any motion failing to obtain the required vote shall preclude the issuance of such findings and order.

The order shall be reduced to writing, executed by the presiding chair of the Board, and filed with the Secretary. A copy of the executed order shall be mailed or hand delivered to each party within five (5) working days after execution by the presiding chair of the Board.
The Board may retain jurisdiction for one (1) year after the order's effective date to modify the order where just cause is found to exist.

para.text: The Board may also impose the following penalties and require the following actions when a public nuisance is found to exist on the property or premises:
Fines not to exceed two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) per day;
Fines not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) per day for recurring public nuisances;
Award reasonable costs, including reasonable attorney fees, associated with investigations of and hearings on public nuisances;

Require the respondent(s) to screen potential tenants or subtenants through a written rental application form, verify information on the application, conduct a criminal record check on each prospective tenant or subtenant, and/or verify identity of applicant(s) through Florida Drivers License, Florida Identification Card, or other comparable form of identification;
Require the lease or other written agreement used by the owner provide rules of conduct relating to criminal activity at the place or premises, violation of which shall be grounds for eviction;
Require the respondent(s) attend meetings of an appropriate neighborhood group or association;
Require the respondent(s) maintain contact and cooperate with the assigned community police officer in carrying out the provisions of the Board's order;

Require that a C.P.T.E.D. (Crime Prevention Through Environmental Design) survey be made of the place or premises and to implement recommendations reasonably related to eliminating factors conducive to criminal conduct;
Require any other procedure(s) the Board deems appropriate to abate a nuisance in a particular case; and
Provide for continuing jurisdiction for a period of one (1) year over any place or premises that has been or is declared to be a public nuisance.
If two (2) or more respondents are fined, the total amount of the fines shall not exceed the maximum amount per day authorized by paragraphs (a)(1) or (a)(2) of this section, as applicable.

If the Board finds two (2) or more respondents responsible for a public nuisance, those respondents will be jointly and severally responsible for complying with the fines and requirements ordered in paragraph (a) of this section.
The total fines imposed pursuant to the authority of this section shall not exceed fifteen thousand dollars ($15,000.00).

As long as the Board maintains jurisdiction over the property, the Board may reduce or eliminate all fines that have accrued against the property and authorize the release of any outstanding liens placed by the city if the Board finds that the owner or the person in charge has taken appropriate corrective steps in good faith to minimize the public nuisance condition or in accordance with the Board's order.

para.text: Any requirement or action imposed by the Board, other than the imposition of fines or award of costs and fees, shall expire one (1) year after its effective date or at such earlier time as is stated in the order.

Any fines imposed or costs and fees awarded by the Board shall continue to be an indebtedness owed to the City of Tampa until satisfied and shall not expire one (1) year after the effective date of the order. Such fines, costs, and fees will become a lien against the property upon the recording of the order as provided in paragraph (c) below.

Any order issued by the Board declaring a place or premises to be a public nuisance that imposes fines, costs, or attorney's fees under the provisions of sections 14-295 and 14-296 shall be recorded with the Clerk of Court, and shall become a lien against the real property that is the subject of the order. However, where the nuisance abatement action is based on a stolen property nuisance, and is brought against a property owner operating an establishment where multiple tenants, on one (1) site, conduct their own retail business, the property owner shall not be subject to a lien against the owner's property or the prohibition of operation provision if the property owner evicts the business declared to be a nuisance within ninety (90) days after notification by registered mail to the property owner of a second stolen property conviction of the tenant.

Fines, costs, or attorney's fees imposed by the Board shall be due and payable upon the date of the order of the Board imposing any and all fines, costs, or attorney's fees. Fines, costs, or attorney's fees may be paid in full without interest during the first thirty (30) calendar days after the date of the order of the Board. Thereafter, interest at the rate established by the Comptroller of the State of Florida pursuant to F.S. §§ 55.03(1) and 687.01, shall accrue upon any unpaid amount of fine(s) and costs.

Any lien recorded against real property may be foreclosed by the city and the owner of such real property shall be liable for all costs, including reasonable attorney fees, associated with the recording of orders and foreclosure. However, no lien created pursuant to the provisions of this section may be foreclosed on real property which is a homestead under Section 4, Article X of the State Constitution.
An order entered under section 14-295 may be enforced pursuant to the procedures contained in F.S. § 120.69.

section.heading: Definitions.
section.text: The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:

Existing establishment: Any premises which operated a business which included the use of simulated gambling devices. In order be considered an existing establishment, the premises must have been legally operating and paid its business tax for each separate location pursuant to chapter 24, article V, Tampa Code of Ordinances as of the effective date of this article. The total number of existing establishments as of the effective date of this article is thirteen (13).

Operator or operation: Any person whose business operation includes a drawing by chance conducted in connection with the sale of a consumer product or service, sweepstakes, or game promotion that utilizes simulated gambling device or a premises in which a simulated gambling devise is conducted.

Person: Any individual, association, partnership, joint venture, corporation, or any other type of organization, whether conducted for profit or not for profit, or a director, executive, officer, manager, or employee of an association, partnership, joint venture, corporation, or other organization.

Premises: The house, building, edifice, parcel, or location, along with its grounds, in or upon which the operator conducts drawings by chance conducted in connection with the sale of a consumer product or service, sweepstakes or game promotions using simulated gambling device.

Simulated gambling device: Any electronic or mechanical device provided by or on behalf of the operator that is used or adapted for use to conduct and/or reveal the results of a drawing by chance conducted in connection with the sale of a consumer product or service, sweepstakes or game promotions that display results by simulating a game or games ordinarily played on a slot machine. This includes the software which is used to conduct the simulated game notwithstanding whether the operator provides the hardware on the premises.

Slot machine: Any mechanical or electrical contrivance, terminal that may or may not be capable of downloading slot games from a central server system, machine, or other device that, upon insertion of a coin, bill, ticket, token, or similar object or upon payment of any monetary consideration whatsoever, including the use of any electronic payment system, is available to play or operate, the play or operation of which, including any element of chance, may deliver or entitle the person or persons playing or operating the contrivance, terminal, machine, or other device to receive cash, billets, tickets, tokens, or electronic credits to be exchanged for cash or to receive merchandise or anything of value whatsoever, whether the payoff is made automatically from the machine or manually. Slot machines may use spinning reels, video displays, cathode ray tubes, microprocessors or other similar technology, and have as their object, the presentation or lining up, arrangement, or juxtaposition of symbols, alphanumeric signs, colors, or figures to determine a result or outcome.

Nothing in this article is intended to conflict with the provisions of the Florida Constitution or F.S. Ch. 849, F.S. §§ 849.0935 and 849.094. In the event of a direct and express conflict between this Article and either the Florida Constitution or F.S. Ch. 849, then the provisions of the Florida Constitution or F.S. Ch. 849, as applicable, control.

section.heading: Legislative intent.
section.text: The intent of the City of Tampa in adopting this article is to broadly prohibit the possession and/or use of simulated gambling devices, including any related activity or behavior which can be reasonably construed to be the use of simulated gambling devices. Further, the City of Tampa, in prohibiting simulated gambling devices, in no way intends to approve the use of actual slot machines, other forms of casino gambling, or other types of gambling devices. In addition, this prohibition is aimed directly at devices that simulate gambling activity, regardless of whether the devices or the simulations in and of themselves constitute gambling. The interests of the citizens of the City of Tampa will be better served if the operation and use of simulated gambling devices is prohibited and existing devises are adequately regulated. This would ensure the limitation of the expanded operation and use of simulated gambling devices within the City of Tampa.

section.heading: Prohibition of simulated gambling devices.
section.text: It is unlawful within the City of Tampa for any person to design, develop, manage, supervise, maintain, provide, produce, possess or use a simulated gambling device. Each individual act to design, develop, manage, supervise, maintain, provide, produce, possess or use a simulated gambling device constitutes a separate violation of this article.

annotation.doc: City of Tampa, Fla., Ord. No. 2013-38

para.text: This article does not prohibit the operation of an existing establishment so long as that existing establishment is operated in conformance with section 14-305.

This article does not prohibit the ownership, possession, play, operation, or use of a computer, video display, or the Internet in a retail business setting provided such ownership, possession, play, operation, or use is not a pretext or sham for using such devices as a simulated gaming device.

This article does not prohibit the ownership, possession, play, operation, or use of any device expressly permitted by the Florida Statutes and not otherwise prohibited by the Florida Constitution. Except for the businesses specifically designated as not intended to be regulated by this article in paragraph (e) below, devices permitted by Article X, Section 23 of the Florida Constitution and F.S. Ch. 551, in Broward and Miami-Dade Counties are not permitted by this article.

This article is specifically not intended to regulate in any manner the following businesses located in the City of Tampa which are currently regulated by federal law, state statute, and/or local ordinance:
Seminole Hard Rock Casino;
Tampa Bay Downs;
Tampa Greyhound Track;
Any properly authorized bingo game establishment;
Any property authorized arcade amusement center, amusement machines, and truck stop arcades operated pursuant to F.S. § 849.161.

para.text: An existing establishment must have been legally operating and paid its business tax for each separate location pursuant to chapter 24, article V, Tampa Code of Ordinances. Upon payment of its business tax prior to October 1, 2013 and for each year thereafter, as required in section 24-105, Tampa Code of Ordinances, each existing establishment shall provide to the business tax manager the following information:
A description of each simulated gambling device in each existing establishment and the total number of each simulated gambling devise on the premises;

The identification by licensor, name and version of any software program that is currently being used by the operator on the simulated gambling device together with the information issued by such licensor for the public specifying the manner in which the software program operates and the computer operation systems and hardware required at a minimum to properly operate the same;
A copy of the operator's proposed rules governing the activities used by the operator on the simulated gambling devices.

An existing establishment is prohibited for offering sale or allowing the consumption of alcoholic beverages on premises except for any existing establishment which currently has an active special use permit for alcoholic beverages.
An existing establishment may only operate on its premises a total number of simulated gaming devises as it had on its premises as of the effective date of this article.
An existing establishment may not relocate to another location.

An existing establishment shall not post any signage or advertisement on the exterior of the premises that suggest gambling takes place on the premises or displays any images commonly associated with gambling or slot machines.
Minors (persons under the age of eighteen (18)) shall not be allowed to enter the premises.
An existing establishment must operate in conformance with all applicable City of Tampa Code of Ordinances, including chapter 24 and chapter 27.

In the event that an existing establishment either fails to remain operational or fails to operate in a manner consistent with this section 14-305, for more than sixty (60) days, then the existing establishment will be deemed abandoned and the continued operation of the premises will be deemed prohibited pursuant to section 14-303.

section.heading: Definitions.
section.text: Conversion therapy or reparative therapy means, interchangeably, any counseling, practice or treatment performed with the goal of changing an individual's sexual orientation or gender identity, including, but not limited to, efforts to change behaviors, gender identity, or gender expression, or to eliminate or reduce sexual or romantic attractions or feelings toward individuals of the same gender or sex. Conversion therapy does not include counseling that provides support and assistance to a person undergoing gender transition or counseling that provides acceptance, support, and understanding of a person or facilitates a person's coping, social support, and development, including sexual orientation-neutral interventions to prevent or address unlawful conduct or unsafe sexual practices, as long as such counseling does not seek to change sexual orientation or gender identity.
Minor means any person less than eighteen (18) years of age.

Provider means any person who is licensed by the State of Florida to provide professional counseling, or who performs counseling as part of his or her professional training under F.S. chs. 456, 458, 459, 490 or 491, as such chapters may be amended, including but not limited to, medical practitioners, osteopathic practitioners, psychologists, psychotherapists, social workers, marriage and family therapists, and licensed counselors. A provider does not include members of the clergy who are acting in their roles as clergy or pastoral counselors and providing religious counseling to congregants, as long as they do not hold themselves out as operating pursuant to any of the aforementioned Florida Statutes licenses.

section.heading: Conversion therapy prohibited.
section.text: It shall be unlawful for any provider to practice conversion therapy efforts on any individual who is a minor regardless of whether the provider receives monetary compensation in exchange for such services.

para.text: This article may be enforced pursuant to chapter 9, article II of this Code.
The violation of section 14-312 of this division is deemed an irreparable or irreversible violation.
Each separate incident of a violation of section 14-312 shall constitute a separate violation for enforcement purposes.
The fine for a first violation of section 14-312 is one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). The fine for a second and subsequent violation(s) of section 14-312 is five thousand dollars ($5,000.00).
These penalties shall not preclude any other remedies available at law or in equity, including, injunctive relief in the circuit court.
